“Miss, I feel bad because I was talking badly about Flo Crit at the hospital and thinking nobody was going to care about me but now that I am here and you are offering me all these nice things I think this is going to be a good place for me.”

Here’s a link to our Wish List: https://amzn.to/2KAha6v Any size contribution will make a big difference in the lives our girls.

We are thrilled to have the opportunity to now offer emergency shelter to girls when they need it most! Girls Ranch Phoenix is a place where girls can come stay for as little as two hours or up to several months until a safe permanent home can be found.

Many of these girls have been removed from unsafe environments and have no where else to go. Girls Ranch Phoenix has the opportunity to provide safe shelter and a place to land. In the few months that our doors have been open, it’s clear that there is a great need for this kind of home.

Each year, we like to recognize an individual who exemplifies the mission of our organization with the HOPE Award. Throughout the month of February, we are celebrating Black History Month by sharing some of our favorite inspiring black women. Today, we celebrate Septima Poinsette Clark. Not only was she an educator, but she also worked as an activist to secure voting rights for black citizens and to see the first black principal in Charleston, North Carolina. President Jimmy Carter presented her with the Living Legacy Award in 1979 in honor of her work toward literacy in African Americans. Through Girls Leadership Academy of Arizona and our various education efforts across our programs, we continue Septima Poinsette Clark's work to provide opportunity through education.

To celebrate Black History Month, we'll be profiling inspirational black women throughout history!

We kick off the celebration with Maggie Lena Walker. In 1903, she was the first African American woman to charter a bank in the US. She also was the editor of a paper, ran an insurance company, owned a department store, and even ran for governor of Virginia! She was able to accomplish this in a time where women didn't even have the right to vote. We celebrate Maggie Lena Walker today as we continue to encourage girls in our care to blaze a trail of leadership.
